settings.blog-title: HOW TO DO YOGA AT HOME

settings.text:
Over the past 5,000 years (or so), yoga has seen incredible growth in popularity, evolving from one of the world’s oldest religious texts into an industry worth billions. Despite the intimidating poses on Instagram and leggings with a triple-figure price tag, yoga is for everyone, and it always has been.

When the world seems to be anything but relaxed and zen, it’s important to find ways to encourage calm within your own bubble. Here’s how to make yoga work for you.

settings.grid-content:
1. What you need

All you really need for an at-home yoga class is your mat. And your self-discipline. However, if you are committed to cultivating a thriving, regular practice at home, there are other useful investments you can make:

A bolster - For reclined or seated meditation, and a much reached-for prop in Yin yoga

A strap - Perfect for beginners or those who need a little help extending their reach

A yoga block - ‘Bring the earth to you’ as many yogis say. Blocks assist with your flexibility without compromising the shape of your posture

settings.text:
Television or tablet - If you wish to follow along with a class

Speaker - If you prefer to play music. Skip this one if you practise in silence

If possible, try to leave your phone in another room to avoid distractions or interruptions.

settings.grid-content:
2. Where can you practise yoga at home?

The beauty of yoga is that there is no perfect setting. In an ideal world, your environment shouldn’t deter what you take away from your practice; of course, this is easier said than done, but it’s a goal to keep in mind. If possible, choose a space that is free of distractions and clutter. Set the mood as much as possible, whether that’s through translucent blinds at the window, dim lights, burning incense or a candle.

3. What can I wear to do yoga at home?

Flexible clothing is ideal for yoga, ones that won’t restrict your movement. Comfort is especially important for an at-home practice, but don’t let an ill-fitting pair of trousers hinder your flexibility. Many budding yogis opt for leggings and a loose T-shirt, or a super comfortable tracksuit for a seamless transition between downtime and that day’s practice.

4. How much time do I need to practise?

The beauty of the at-home yoga practice is that you can structure your “classes” around your own life. Whilst studio classes can range from one hour to 90 minutes in length, many yoga teachers will insist that no effort is too short. Whether you have six or 60 minutes to spare, there are always rewards to be reaped.

Slot your practice into your life. If you work from home you may prefer to indulge in a morning flow before the working day begins. Or if you have young children, a relaxing evening stretch after bath and bed might suit your schedule better.

5. Different types of yoga

An important aspect of pursuing an at-home yoga practice is finding a style that you prefer. You may prefer a gentle stretch or flow, or you might want to break a sweat every now and then.

Hatha - A Sanskrit word that encompasses all physical forms of yoga. In modern, Western practices, Hatha refers is a gentle flow accessible to all abilities

Yin-Yang - Yin targets the deep connective tissues between your muscles by having you hold poses for up to 10 minutes. This instills calm and increases circulation to your joints

settings.text:
Nidra - Also known as ‘yogic sleep’, is a tremendously powerful form of meditation. One of the easiest forms of yoga, in terms of postures, but also the most mentally difficult

Qi Jong - Bearing similar elements to tai chi, Qi Jong focuses on deep restoration through gentle moving meditation and focused breathing

Kundalini - An energy-focused practice that involves singing, chanting, breathing and repetitive poses

Iyengar - With a strong focus on alignment and form, Iyengar uses props and is great for injury recovery and rehabilitation

Jivamukti - A powerful and structured practice that doesn’t shy away from the spiritual side of yoga

Ashtanga - A high-energy flow that follows a specific structure

Vinyasa - The focus here is on stringing postures together with the aim of moving from one to another as seamlessly as possible, all connected by the breath

settings.grid-content:
6. Best online classes

Many at-home yogis choose to follow the guidance of professionals from the comfort of their own home, rather than making time for regular visits to a studio. Whether you prefer the soothing tones of a teacher emanating from your television or would rather go with your own flow, there are a number of great online platforms to choose from.

Yoga With Adriene - The original YouTube yogi. Adriene’s free classes range from six minutes to full-hour practices. She has a video for all ailments and areas, with almost every upload featuring a not-so surprise appearance from her sidekick, Benji.

Do Yoga With Me - Featuring yoga teachers from around the world, Do Yoga With Me caters to all abilities and all styles.

These are two of our favourite digital yoga platforms. For more, read our guide on the best online classes the internet has to offer.

The internet brings yoga to you. Whether you’re new to classes or want to supplement your existing studio practice, designing your own at-home practice gives you freedom, privacy, and above all, flexibility in every sense of the word.

settings.text:
Be the gateway

Don’t let your hard work go to waste by re-filling your newly detoxed closet as soon as the sales arrive. If you’re truly committed to keeping your wardrobe lean and organised, you could adopt a one-in, one-out policy, or simply track your spending and keep notes on which pieces you already have.

But, if you come across something that fills you with joy, then by all means invest.
